text: Mathilde Radiguet (born 1984) is a French geophysicist, specializing in the mechanics of faults and the study of transient deformations. In 2019, she won a French National Centre for Scientific Research (CNRS) bronze medal. She studied geophysics at École Normale Supérieure. She studied on the relationship between soil movements and fault characteristics at the Institute of Earth Sciences (ISTerre) with F. Cotton, I. Manighetti and M. Campillo. She obtained her PhD in geophysics from the Grenoble Alpes University. She was a post-doctoral fellow at École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne, where she worked on modelling the dynamics of rupture. She is a professor at Grenoble Observatory for Sciences of the Universe.
